The Rakiura track is a tramping (hiking) track situated in the Rakiura National Park, in the

at the south of  of New Zealand. 

The Rakiura track is 32km long, but the complete route to / from the village of Oban is 39km including sections on the road at either end. Entry to the track is at sea level, and the highest point is approximately 200m. 

The track may be walked in either direction and form a circular route to / from Oban, where there are ferries / flights from near

. The track is normally walked in three days, but if you can keep up a good pace, can be done in 2 days or 1 long day in summer.

The track features huts and campsites. These must be booked in advance through the Department of Conservation. There are several places to stay in and around Oban, this is best booked in advance.

The route described here goes anti-clockwise around the track. This means that you have the longest road section of route at the start.

5km

From the centre of Oban follow Horseshoe Bay Road up over a small hill to Horseshoe bay beach. As an alternative there is a track around the coast Horseshoe Point Track, but this is a bit of detour.

Then walk along (or around) the beach and take Lee Bay Road at the far end of the bay. The official start of the track is by the beach at Lee Bay.

value: Lee bay to Port William Hut
File:Lee Bay at the start of the Rakiura Track.JPG
Lee Bay and the chain link sculpture near the start of the Rakiura Track.

8.1km

The track follows the coast to Magnetic Bay. Here the route turns inland, but Port William hut is a small diversion to the north at the other end of the beach.

value: Port William Hut to North Arm Hut

13km

This section is inland through lush forest.

value: North Arm Hut to Fern Gully

11km

This section losley follows the coast of the Paterson Inlet to the main road near the airstrip.

2km

It is then a short walk on Main Road down to Half Moon Bay.
Ensure you follow the precautions outlined on the Department of Conservation brochures and any other information provided to you.
